definition:
The $x$- and $y$-axes the $xy$-plane in four right-angle domains which
are called the [*quadrants*]{} of the plane. They are numbered going
round the origin in anticlockwise direction so that
$$\{(x,\,y) \mid \;  x > 0,\; y > 0\}$$ is the [*first quadrant*]{},
$$\{(x,\,y) \mid \;  x < 0,\; y > 0\}$$ the [*second quadrant*]{}, and
so on.

Naturally, one can speak of the quadrants of the complex plane, too.\
The lines $y = \pm x$ have as their slope angles $\pm 45^\circ$, thus
halving the quadrant angles; they are called the [*quadrant
bisectors*]{}. Cf. angle bisector as locus.
